Answer: To ensure that you are reading the body data starting from the correct position in the inputstream, you should first read the headers and then use the Content-Length header to determine the length of the body data. Once you have the length, you can then read that amount of data from the inputstream. Here is an example of how you can modify your code:

```java
InputStream stream = socket.getInputStream();
HashMap<String, String> headers = new HashMap<String, String>();
byte [] buffer = new byte[8*1024];
stream.read(buffer, 0, 8*1024);
ByteArrayInputStream bytestream = new ByteArrayInputStream(buffer);
InputStreamReader streamReader = new InputStreamReader(bytestream);
BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(streamReader);
String requestline = reader.readLine();

for (;;) {
    String line = reader.readLine();
    if (line.equals(""))
        break;
    String[] header = line.split(":", 2);
    headers.put(header[0], header[1]); //TODO: check for bad header
}

// Check if content length is present in headers
if (headers.containsKey("Content-Length")) {
    int contentLength = Integer.parseInt(headers.get("Content-Length"));
    byte[] bodyBuffer = new byte[contentLength];
    stream.read(bodyBuffer, 0, contentLength);
    // Now you can process the body data from bodyBuffer
}
```

This way, you are ensuring that you are reading the body data starting from the correct position in the inputstream.

Note: This code assumes that the Content-Length header is present in the request. If it's not, you should handle the case where the header is missing.

Also, remember to close the inputstream when you're done reading from it to free up system resources.
